intro: Rhysolepis salicifolia, commonly known as the redstem dogwood, is a deciduous shrub native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its slender, red-hued stems and opposite, ovate leaves that are typically gray-green in color. The plant produces small, white to greenish flowers in clusters during the spring, followed by red or orange berries in the fall. Its foliage and berries provide food for various birds and small mammals. Rhysolepis salicifolia is often found in moist, shaded habitats such as woodlands and stream banks.
